title: Why does the same song have two versions of lyrics? - Quora

response.answer_text: Because music, as an art form, is neither stagnant nor fixed; and the artist retains control over what they want that artistic representation to say. It is said that Leonard Cohen wrote at least seventy-five verses for “Hallelujah”. It’s doubtful that even half of them were recorded, or that two-thirds would have even been performed more than once. Sometimes a different turn of phrase is realized by the songwriter later, and they want to capture that emotion a little more carefully. Occasionally you’ll get whole lines cut or added. “In Your Eyes” by Peter Gabriel comes to mind, as he’s taken to skipping the line “I see the doorway to a thousand churches” the first time the chorus runs in most concerts in everything I’ve heard or watched in the past twenty-odd years. Why? Might’ve been a mistake. Might’ve been a wish to save that emotion for later in the song, and build to it. I personally prefer the original, but dude…the guy’s Peter Gabriel. It’s the same thing as asking about remakes, especially if the remake is significantly different from the original. Listen to “Layla” from Derek and the Dominoes, then listen to it off Clapton’s “Unplugged” album. It’s the same guy, the same songwriter, the same vocalist, the same guitarist, and yet they are two completely different versions. Why? Because he wanted to. He felt the need to explore it differently. Songs are expressions of emotion, and emotions aren’t static. So why should songs be?
